tonegod.gui.controls.lists

Class Table

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.jme3.scene.Spatial
      • com.jme3.scene.Node
        • tonegod.gui.core.Element
          • tonegod.gui.controls.scrolling.ScrollArea
            • tonegod.gui.controls.lists.Table
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.jme3.asset.CloneableSmartAsset, com.jme3.collision.Collidable, com.jme3.export.Savable, com.jme3.util.clone.JmeCloneable, java.lang.Cloneable, FlingListener, KeyboardListener, MouseButtonListener, MouseMovementListener, MouseWheelListener, TabFocusListener, TouchListener

    public abstract class Table
extends ScrollArea
implements MouseMovementListener, MouseWheelListener, MouseButtonListener, TabFocusListener, KeyboardListener
    A table control that can act like a tree, a table, a tree table or a list, depending on configuration.

    Features include :-

    • Sortable columns
    • Resizable columns
    • Auto-size columns
    • Single / multiple, row / cell selection
    • Nested rows possible, which activates tree features
    • Hideable header
    • Keyboard navigation

    Cells are either strings, or you may use any Element.

    Example of a simple Table using string cells

    Panel panel = new Panel(screen, "Panel", new Vector2f(8, 8), new Vector2f(372f, 300)); final Table table = new Table(screen, new Vector2f(10, 40)) { public void onChange() { // Invoked when selection changes. } }; table.setColumnResizeMode(Table.ColumnResizeMode.AUTO_FIRST); table.addColumn("Column 1"); table.addColumn("Column 2"); table.addColumn("Column 3"); for (int i = 0; i < 20; * i++) { Table.TableRow row = new Table.TableRow(screen, table); row.addCell(String.format("Row %d, Cell 1", i), i); row.addCell(String.format("Row %d, Cell 2", i), i); row.addCell(String.format("Row %d, Cell 3", i), i); table.addRow(row); } panel.addChild(table);

    Example of a Tree Table

    To configure as a Tree Table features, you need set a row as NOT being a 'leaf', and then add child rows to the other rows :- final Table table = new TreeTable(screen, new Vector2f(10, 40)) { public void onChange() { } }; table.addColumn("Column 1"); table.addColumn("Column 2"); table.addColumn("Column 3"); Table.TableRow parentRow = new Table.TableRow(screen, table); parentRow.setLeaf(false); * parentRow.addCell("A", "1"); parentRow.addCell("B", "2"); parentRow.addCell("C", "3"); table.addRow(parentRow); Table.TableRow childRow = new Table.TableRow(screen, table); childRow.addCell("AA", "11"); childRow.addCell("Bb", "22"); childRow.addCell("CC", "33"); childRow.addRow(childRow);

    Example of a Tree

    To configure as a Tree , it is much the same as a Tree Table, except just add a single column, and hide the headers. :- final Table table = new Table(screen, new Vector2f(10, 40)) { public void onChange() { } }; table.setHeadersVisible(false); table.addColumn("Column"); Table.TableRow parentRow = new Table.TableRow(screen, table); parentRow.setLeaf(false); parentRow.addCell("A", "1"); table.addRow(parentRow); Table.TableRow childRow = new Table.TableRow(screen, table); childRow.addCell("AA", "11"); childRow.addRow(childRow);

    Example of a List

    As an alternative to the building in lists, you can use this control, turn off the headers and add on a single column, to a single depth. :- final Table table = new Table(screen, new Vector2f(10, 40)) { public void onChange() { } }; table.setHeadersVisible(false); table.addColumn("Column"); Table.TableRow row1 = new Table.TableRow(screen, table); table.addCell("A", "1"); table.addRow(row1); Table.TableRow row2 = new Table.TableRow(screen, table); parentRow.addCell("B", "2"); table.addRow(row2);

      • addRow

        public int addRow(Table.TableRow row,
                  boolean pack)
        Adds a TableRow to the Table and optionally calls pack() to recalculate layout. Note, if you have lots of rows to add, it is much faster to add them all, then call pack() once when you are done.
        Parameters:
        row - row
        pack - recalculate layout
        Returns:
        index of the last row

      • addRow

        public int addRow(Table.TableRow row)
        Adds a TableRow to the Table and calls pack() to recalculate layout. See addRow(tonegod.gui.controls.lists.Table.TableRow, boolean) for an explanation of the impact of always packing when you add items.
        Parameters:
        row - row
        Returns:
        index of the last row

      • insertRow

        public void insertRow(int index,
                      Table.TableRow row,
                      boolean pack)
        Inserts a new row at the provided index and optionally calls pack() to recalculate layout. Note, if you have lots of rows to insert, it is much faster to insert them all, then call pack() once when you are done.
        Parameters:
        index - The index to insert into
        row - The row to insert
        pack - recalculate layout

      • insertRow

        public void insertRow(int index,
                      Table.TableRow row)
        Inserts a new row at the provided index and calls pack() to recalculate layout. See insertRow(int, tonegod.gui.controls.lists.Table.TableRow, boolean) for an explanation of the impact of always packing when you insert items.
        Parameters:
        index - The index to insert into
        row - The row to insert

      • removeRow

        public void removeRow(int index,
                      boolean pack)
        Remove the row at the provided index and optionally calls pack() to recalculate layout. Note, if you have lots of rows to insert, it is much faster to insert them all, then call pack() once when you are done.
        Parameters:
        index - int
        pack - recalculate layout

      • removeRow

        public void removeRow(int index)
        Remove the row at the provided index and calls pack() to recalculate layout. See removeRow(int, boolean) for an explanation of the impact of always packing when you remove items.
        Parameters:
        index - int

        public int[] getSelectedCell()

      • pack

        public void pack()
        Forces the Table to rebuild all TableRows. This does not need to be called if you use the methods that automatically packed when rows are added or removed.
